section.title: Java Configuration
section.para: These sub-sections cover the different aspects of the Java Virtual Machine required for executing Java based Eclipse SCADA Applications.

section.title: Locating the Java Virtual Machine

note.para: This section applies to Unix based systems.

section.para: By default Eclipse SCADA will install a set of shell scripts which manage starting and stopping the different Eclipse SCADA applications. These shell script will use the following mechanism to locate Java.

listitem.para: If JAVA_HOME is set, it will be used
If JRE_HOME is set, it will be used
Use the java virtual machine found on the path

note.para: If JAVA_HOME or JRE_HOME are set to a path that is not existing, the execution will fail. The scripts do not switch to the next possible option.

section.para: The variables can either be set in the files /etc/sysconfig/eclipsescada or /etc/default/eclipsescada or using some system way for setting environment variables (e.g. /etc/profile.d). This is also the order of defining. This means that while you system may specific a JAVA_HOME already, it is possible to override for Eclipse SCADA using the sysconfig or default file.
If neither environment variable is set, then the scripts will fall back to using the Java Virtual Machine from the PATH. This can normally be configured using the command update-java-alternatives.

warning.title: Java 7+
warning.para: While it is possible to select a Java 6 (or earlier) JVM using update-java-alternatives or the environment variables, still Eclipse SCADA won't work with Java versions 6 or earlier.
